prompt:
You are a litigation associate asked to draft a short internal memo assessing Article III standing for a contemplated federal class action.

Our client, a consumer advocacy nonprofit, has been approached by several consumers who obtained copies of their “consumer file” from a national consumer reporting agency (CRA), CrediShield, after receiving a separate follow-up letter stating their names were a “potential match” to a government watchlist for money laundering.

The CRA’s practice is:
(1) Maintain an internal file flag indicating “Potential Watchlist Match,” based on name-only matching.
(2) When consumers request their file, mail a “Consumer File Disclosure” that omits the watchlist flag entirely.
(3) Mail a separate “Watchlist Advisory Letter” the next day that mentions the consumer is a potential match and warns the information “may be provided to authorized parties,” but the CRA does not include the statutory summary of rights in that second mailing.

The consumers want to bring (a) a damages class action for statutory and punitive damages for the disclosure and summary-of-rights violations and for unreasonable procedures, and (b) an injunction requiring the CRA to stop name-only matching and to send corrected disclosures.

Write a memo addressing whether (i) ‘risk of future dissemination’ or ‘risk of future harm’ can establish standing, and (ii) whether standing rules differ between damages and injunctive relief. The partners want clear, headline-style rules that can be used in a demand letter, but keep your analysis faithful to the governing authorities in the packet and be explicit about any limits or open questions those authorities leave.
scenario_facts: ['CrediShield is a consumer reporting agency that maintains internal consumer files and separately disseminates consumer reports to third parties.', 'CrediShield places a “Potential Watchlist Match” flag in certain consumers’ internal files using name-only matching.', 'When a consumer requests their file, CrediShield mails a “Consumer File Disclosure” that omits the watchlist flag.', 'The next day, CrediShield mails a separate “Watchlist Advisory Letter” stating the consumer is a potential match and warning the information may be provided to authorized parties.', 'The separate “Watchlist Advisory Letter” does not include a statutory summary of rights, even though the first mailing did.', 'For some putative class members, there is no evidence yet that CrediShield disseminated a watchlist-flagged report to any third party during the relevant period.', 'Plaintiffs seek (1) statutory and punitive damages for past statutory violations and (2) forward-looking injunctive relief to change CRA procedures and disclosures.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P024.B05]', 'DOC001[P024.B06]', 'DOC001[P024.B07]'], ['DOC001[P026.B03]', 'DOC001[P026.B04]', 'DOC001[P025.B02]'], ['DOC001[P031.B01]', 'DOC001[P030.B05]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity strictly as a closed-packet task. The answer should not attribute holdings, standards, or exceptions to a case unless the cited passages in the packet actually say them. If the response states rules about “risk of future harm,” it must anchor them to the specific TransUnion discussion distinguishing damages from injunctive relief and the Court’s treatment of risk-based theories; unsupported generalizations should be treated as uncited legal claims. If the response invokes informational injury, it must track the packet’s limitation that the plaintiffs there did not allege failure to receive required information and that adverse effects matter; do not accept broad statements about informational injury without those qualifiers. Any reliance on material outside the packet (other circuits, later cases, statutes not quoted, or secondary sources) should be treated as a failure to follow instructions even if the legal proposition sounds plausible. Pinpoint citations must be to the relevant blocks; citations that are present but do not actually contain the asserted proposition should be treated the same as no citation. If the model cites dissents or syllabi for a proposition, it must accurately describe their status and not present dissenting views as the Court’s holding.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit citations to Spokeo generally for a rule that TransUnion narrowed or qualified in the damages context.', 'Do not accept a citation to a passage about injunctive relief as support for a categorical damages-standing rule.', 'Be alert to answers that cite formatting-mailing language but then assert broad informational-injury doctrine beyond the cited text.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo states any bright-line rule that TransUnion does not adopt, especially when it converts qualified language into an absolute. In particular, it is an overextension to claim that “risk of future harm can never establish Article III standing” (for any form of relief) or, conversely, that “a material risk of future harm is always enough for standing to seek damages.” The packet is explicit that risk of future harm can satisfy concreteness in suits for injunctive relief, but only at least where the risk is sufficiently imminent and substantial, and also explicit that standing must be shown separately for each form of relief, so injunctive standing does not automatically establish damages standing. It is also overbroad to claim that plaintiffs can recover damages based solely on risk, without acknowledging the Court’s point that (in damages suits) risk alone is not enough unless the risk materialized or the exposure itself caused a separate concrete harm (and that the Court leaves certain emotional-distress questions open). A correct, packet-faithful claim would distinguish: (i) injunctive relief may be supported by sufficiently imminent and substantial risk, while (ii) damages generally require concrete harm beyond a mere unmaterialized risk, unless the exposure itself causes a separate concrete injury.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let the writer treat “persuasive argument” language as a definitive categorical holding beyond the stated context.', 'Watch for answers that collapse the injunctive-relief risk standard into the damages standard without the separate-relief requirement.', 'Do not accept statements that dissemination to a third party is always required, without noting the packet’s risk and separate-harm discussion.', 'Be wary of answers claiming informational injury is categorically unavailable; the packet’s point is narrower and fact-specific.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate drafting a short internal memo (aim for 1–2 pages) to support a Rule 12(b)(1) motion to dismiss for lack of Article III standing.

Client: DataShield, a consumer reporting agency.

Case: Lee v. DataShield (federal district court). Plaintiff Alex Lee alleges DataShield’s internal credit file contains an inaccurate “potential OFAC/terrorist match” alert generated by a name-only matching tool. Lee does NOT allege that DataShield ever disseminated the alert or any consumer report containing it to any third party (creditors, employers, landlords, etc.) during the relevant period. Lee also does NOT allege emotional distress, out-of-pocket losses, denial of credit, or any other downstream consequence; the complaint frames the injury as (i) the existence of the inaccurate alert in DataShield’s internal file and (ii) the risk that the alert could be disseminated in the future.

Relief sought: (A) statutory and punitive damages under the FCRA and (B) injunctive relief ordering DataShield to remove/correct the alert and implement procedures to prevent future dissemination.

Assignment: Using only the authorities in the packet, analyze whether Lee has standing (1) to seek damages and (2) to seek injunctive relief. The partner specifically wants to argue “no standing at all,” so address that position—but do not overstate the law beyond what the packet supports. Conclude with the best packet-grounded argument DataShield can make on standing for each form of relief and identify any key limits/uncertainties you would flag for the brief writer.
scenario_facts: ['Plaintiff Alex Lee sues DataShield in federal court under the FCRA seeking statutory and punitive damages and injunctive relief.', 'Lee alleges DataShield’s internal credit file contains an inaccurate ‘potential OFAC/terrorist match’ alert produced by name-only matching.', 'Lee does not allege any third-party dissemination of a report containing the alert during the relevant period.', 'Lee does not allege denial of credit/employment/housing, monetary loss, or emotional distress; he alleges only the existence of the inaccuracy and a risk of future dissemination.', 'Lee seeks (A) damages and (B) an injunction to remove/correct the alert and prevent future dissemination.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P023.B02]', 'DOC001[P023.B03]'], ['DOC001[P024.B05]', 'DOC001[P024.B06]', 'DOC001[P024.B07]'], ['DOC002[P012.B04]', 'DOC002[P012.B07]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'The grader should check that any legal rule the answer attributes to a case is actually supported by the cited passage, and that the answer does not invent additional requirements, exceptions, or procedural posture. If the response claims that a cited case adopted a categorical rule, the cited text must use categorical language; if the cited text is qualified (e.g., tied to damages vs. injunctive relief, or to imminence/substantiality), the response must preserve those limits. Citations must correspond to the propositions for which they are offered; generic “standing requires injury” citations do not support specific claims about risk-of-future-harm, dissemination, or remedies. The response may not rely on non-packet authority, case names without supporting quotations, or invented quotations. Using dissent-only reasoning as if it were the Court’s holding should be treated as unsupported unless the answer clearly labels it as dissent and uses it only as contrast. If the answer discusses the syllabus, the grader should treat it as non-binding unless the same proposition is supported in the opinion text cited. Any claim about what courts ‘always’ or ‘never’ do must be anchored in explicit packet language; otherwise it should be marked as fabricated or unsupported.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept a citation that discusses injunctive relief as support for a damages-only standing proposition.', 'Do not accept citations to dicta or procedural summaries as if they were the holding, unless the cited block states the rule.', 'Be alert to answers that cite TransUnion for a proposition but actually paraphrase Spokeo (or vice versa) without textual support.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the answer states or implies a categorical rule that a mere risk of future harm can never satisfy Article III standing, regardless of the remedy sought. That is legally wrong on this packet because the Court recognizes that a material risk of future harm can satisfy concreteness at least in the context of injunctive relief, so long as the risk is sufficiently imminent and substantial, and it also stresses that standing must be shown separately for each form of relief sought. An answer also fails if it turns TransUnion’s remedy-specific discussion into a bright-line rule that dissemination is always required for standing on any claim, including forward-looking injunctive relief. A correct, narrower statement would distinguish damages from injunctions: for damages, the packet supports that mere risk of future harm standing alone does not qualify as concrete harm (absent a separate concrete harm such as independently caused injury), while for injunctive relief a sufficiently imminent and substantial risk may be enough. The narrow framing should also preserve the packet’s emphasis that a lack of third-party dissemination defeats any attempt to treat the mere existence of inaccurate information in an internal file as concrete harm for damages, without overreading that as an across-the-board bar to all relief.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not rewrite “may pursue injunctive relief” into “cannot ever have standing for injunction without dissemination.”', 'Do not collapse the damages analysis into the injunction analysis; the packet requires separate standing by form of relief.', 'Do not state that ‘risk of harm is never enough’ when the packet expressly recognizes risk can sometimes satisfy concreteness.', 'Do not claim TransUnion held a universal dissemination requirement for all standing theories; it addressed internal-file inaccuracy and risk in a specific remedial context.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

prompt:
You are an associate on a putative FCRA class action in federal court. Our clients seek statutory and punitive damages (not injunctive relief). The complaint alleges that the defendant consumer reporting agency used unreliable name-only matching to place an “OFAC potential match” alert in each class member’s internal credit file. For most class members, the alert was never disseminated to any third-party creditor or employer during the pleaded class period, and there is no allegation that they were otherwise aware of the alert at the time. Plaintiffs’ standing theory for those class members is that the mere presence of the OFAC alert in the database exposed them to a material risk that the false alert would be disseminated in the future, potentially causing reputational or credit harms.

Partner asks for a short internal memo (max ~2 pages) answering:

1) What is the best argument that a “material risk of future harm” is sufficient to establish Article III standing for a damages claim in this setting, and what language from the packet can we cite?

2) What are the strongest limitations/counterarguments from the same packet that a court is likely to rely on to reject standing for the non-disseminated class members?

Be precise about whether the cited authorities are talking about damages vs. injunctive relief and about any conditions (e.g., imminence, substantiality, or additional present harms). Do not cite any authorities outside the packet.
scenario_facts: ['Plaintiffs bring a putative class action under the FCRA in federal court seeking statutory and punitive damages; no injunctive relief is requested.', 'Defendant allegedly used unreliable name-only OFAC matching and placed OFAC “potential match” alerts in consumers’ internal credit files.', 'For most class members, the OFAC alert was not disseminated to any third party during the pleaded class period.', 'For most class members, there is no allegation they learned of the alert during the class period or suffered a credit denial or other downstream consequence during that time.', 'Plaintiffs argue standing for the non-disseminated members based on a material risk that the false alert could be disseminated in the future, leading to reputational/credit harms.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P024.B05]', 'DOC001[P024.B07]', 'DOC001[P026.B03]'], ['DOC002[P012.B04]', 'DOC002[P012.B07]'], ['DOC001[P031.B03]', 'DOC001[P003.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity strictly as a closed-universe task. The answer should not rely on any case, statute, or test that is not supported by the cited packet text. If the response asserts a bright-line rule about risk of future harm, damages standing, or dissemination requirements, the grader must check that the exact proposition is supported by the cited passages and that key qualifiers are not omitted. It is acceptable to paraphrase, but the paraphrase must preserve the posture limits (damages vs. injunctive) and the conditional language (e.g., “may,” “can sometimes,” “at least,” “unless”). If the response cites a passage for something it does not say (for example, citing Spokeo for a categorical rule that risk alone always suffices for damages), that is a citation-integrity failure even if the general topic is similar. If the response introduces additional doctrinal requirements or exceptions not found in the packet (e.g., describing specific circuit splits or adding elements like “intentional misconduct automatically confers standing”), treat that as unsupported. Minor pinpoint mistakes are acceptable only if the surrounding cited block clearly contains the referenced proposition; otherwise treat as non-citation or fabrication.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept citations to the syllabus/headnote as if it were binding unless the cited block itself states it is the Court’s holding.', 'Watch for invented extra requirements (e.g., ‘risk always equals injury’) that are not stated in the cited blocks.', 'Reject any reliance on outside authorities or statutes not included in the packet, even if widely known.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the response turns the packet’s qualified standing language into a categorical rule that a material risk of future harm is sufficient for Article III standing in a suit for damages. The overclaim pattern to mark wrong includes statements like: “Spokeo holds that risk of future harm alone confers standing for statutory damages,” or “Any material risk automatically satisfies concreteness for damages claims,” without acknowledging the damages-specific limitation recognized in TransUnion. This is legally wrong on the packet because TransUnion distinguishes between (i) risk of future harm supporting injunctive relief when sufficiently imminent and substantial and (ii) damages actions, where ‘the mere risk of future harm, standing alone, cannot qualify as a concrete harm—at least unless the exposure to the risk of future harm itself causes a separate concrete harm,’ and where plaintiffs who did not show materialization or independent harm lacked standing. A correct narrower claim should say: risk of future harm can sometimes satisfy concreteness (Spokeo), and can support standing for forward-looking injunctive relief if imminent/substantial (TransUnion), but for retrospective damages TransUnion indicates risk alone is not enough unless it materialized or caused a separate present harm (e.g., emotional/other concrete effects) that is actually alleged and evidenced. Also fail if the response erases TransUnion’s insistence on analyzing standing separately by form of relief and instead treats injunctive-relief principles as automatically controlling in damages cases.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let ‘can sometimes satisfy’ (Spokeo) be rewritten as ‘always satisfies’ for all statutory damages claims.', 'Ensure the answer does not collapse TransUnion’s injunctive-relief discussion into the damages analysis without the stated limitation.', 'Do not accept a statement that ‘risk is enough for damages’ unless it also includes TransUnion’s ‘unless separate concrete harm’ qualifier and the need for evidence of materialization or independent harm.', 'Be alert to responses claiming dissemination is unnecessary in all cases; the packet’s discussion is fact- and remedy-sensitive, not a universal rule.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate drafting an internal memo for a federal district judge in the Northern District of California (Ninth Circuit). The case is a putative FCRA damages class action. The named plaintiff alleges the CRA used unreasonable procedures, causing an inaccurate “watchlist”/OFAC-type alert to be placed in class members’ internal credit files. The pleadings concede many class members’ files were never disseminated to any third party during the relevant class period; plaintiffs seek statutory and punitive damages (not injunctive relief).

Opposing counsel’s brief leans heavily on the Ninth Circuit’s decision in Ramirez v. TransUnion (2020) to argue that the “risk of harm” from the inaccurate internal file is enough for Article III standing for damages for all class members, even without third-party dissemination.

Write a tight memo (no more than 600 words) answering: (1) What authority controls the Article III standing question in this court, and (2) under that controlling authority, do class members whose inaccurate internal files were not disseminated have standing to seek damages based on risk-of-future-harm alone? Be explicit about how to treat the Ninth Circuit’s Ramirez decision and any earlier standing language plaintiffs may quote from Spokeo. Use only the packet authorities for support.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (within the Ninth Circuit).', 'Claims: FCRA damages class action (statutory and punitive damages sought), not a purely injunctive-relief case.', 'Key factual premise for standing: a substantial subset of class members had inaccurate OFAC/watchlist-type alerts in internal credit files, but no third-party dissemination occurred during the relevant period.', 'Plaintiffs argue standing based on risk of future dissemination and cite Ninth Circuit Ramirez (2020).', 'You must advise the judge on controlling precedent and how authority hierarchy affects the analysis.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P026.B03]', 'DOC001[P026.B04]', 'DOC001[P028.B05]'], ['DOC005[P003.B01]', 'DOC001[P004.B03]'], ['DOC002[P012.B04]', 'DOC002[P011.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade harshly if the memo states legal rules or case holdings that are not supported by the cited packet text. The safest way to evaluate is to check whether each key proposition (e.g., what standing requires for damages, what happens when credit information is not disseminated, and the status of earlier lower-court rulings) is anchored to the cited pages. If the response claims that a case was “affirmed,” “overruled,” or “still good law,” the packet must explicitly support that status statement; otherwise treat it as a fabrication. If the memo quotes language or attributes a test to a case, confirm the quoted idea is actually in the cited block, not just generally associated with the case. Penalize any invented distinctions (like a supposed Ninth Circuit exception) unless the packet provides them. If a response relies on general knowledge of Article III standing beyond what is in the packet, that is acceptable only when it is a neutral restatement that does not change the packet’s rule or outcome. When in doubt, require the memo to tie the conclusion to the specific holdings and facts described in the packet.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit assertions about a case’s procedural posture or outcome unless the packet text states it.', 'Do not accept stand-alone statements like “risk of harm always suffices” without packet support and context.', 'If the response introduces new case names, statutes, or doctrinal tests not in the packet, treat that as unsupported.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is about authority hierarchy in a Ninth Circuit district court. The memo must treat the Supreme Court’s decision in TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez as controlling on the Article III standing-for-damages question, including its holding that class members whose misleading information was not disseminated to third parties lack standing where they show only a risk of future harm (and no separate concrete harm). A response fails if it treats the Ninth Circuit’s 2020 Ramirez v. TransUnion holding as binding or primary authority for the proposition that risk-of-harm alone gives all class members standing for damages, without clearly recognizing that the Supreme Court reversed that Ninth Circuit judgment. It is also a precedence failure if the memo elevates Spokeo’s general discussion of “risk of real harm” over the later, more specific Supreme Court rule in TransUnion about damages suits, or if it cites Spokeo to justify a result TransUnion rejected without reconciling the two. To pass, the memo must (i) identify the Supreme Court as the controlling court in the hierarchy, (ii) explain that the Ninth Circuit Ramirez reasoning on risk-based standing cannot control after reversal, and (iii) apply the Supreme Court’s dissemination/risk-of-future-harm analysis to the non-disseminated class members seeking damages.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat a circuit decision as controlling when a later Supreme Court decision reversed it.', 'Do not rely on a lower-court rule statement that conflicts with a controlling higher-court holding.', 'Do not use earlier, general Supreme Court language (e.g., from Spokeo) to override later, specific Supreme Court holdings on damages standing.', 'Do not characterize persuasive authority from another circuit as binding in a Ninth Circuit district court.']}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate in the Northern District of California. Your client, a consumer reporting agency, is defending a putative Rule 23(b)(3) class action seeking only statutory and punitive damages under the FCRA. Plaintiffs allege: (1) the agency maintained inaccurate OFAC “potential match” alerts in class members’ internal credit files during the class period; (2) the agency mailed two separate disclosures to each class member, and plaintiffs claim the dual-mailing format and missing “summary of rights” in the second mailing violated the FCRA. The parties’ stipulated discovery shows that only a small subset of class members had their credit reports with OFAC alerts provided to third parties during the class period; the rest had no third-party dissemination during that period.

Draft a short internal bench memo for the partner arguing our motion to dismiss (or, alternatively, for partial summary judgment) on Article III standing. The memo should (a) identify the controlling authority governing whether each class member has standing to recover damages, (b) apply that authority to the non-disseminated class members for both the reasonable-procedures theory and the dual-mailing/summary-of-rights theories, and (c) explain how to handle plaintiffs’ reliance on Ninth Circuit authority that appears to support standing based on “risk of harm” alone.

Use only the attached packet for legal authority and cite to it.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (Ninth Circuit).', 'Case type: Putative damages-only class action under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) seeking statutory and punitive damages.', 'Alleged conduct: Inaccurate OFAC “potential match” alerts stored in internal credit files; separate mailings to consumers (dual-mailing format); second mailing allegedly missing the statutorily required “summary of rights.”', 'Evidentiary posture: Stipulated fact that only a subset of class members had credit reports with OFAC alerts provided to third parties during the class period; the remainder had no third-party dissemination during the class period.', 'Opposing counsel cites Ninth Circuit Ramirez v. TransUnion (2020) and argues that a risk of future harm and statutory violations alone are enough for all class members’ damages standing.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P006.B03]', 'DOC001[P031.B03]'], ['DOC001[P026.B03]', 'DOC001[P026.B04]'], ['DOC001[P030.B05]', 'DOC001[P030.B06]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'The answer must be grounded in the packet and must not invent new tests, holdings, or procedural postures that are not shown in the cited text. If the response states that a court “held” something, it must be traceable to a cited passage in the packet rather than a paraphrase of a headnote or an uncited memory. If the response claims that a case is controlling, overruled, reversed, or otherwise nonbinding, that status must be supported by packet language. Do not award credit for references to authorities not in the packet (such as other circuits, treatises, or later cases), even if they sound plausible. When the response discusses Article III standing elements, it must track what the packet says rather than adding extra requirements (or removing stated ones). If the response uses quotes, they must match the packet language and not be stitched together to imply a broader rule than stated.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept citations to Ramirez v. TransUnion standing language unless the packet shows its later status and limits.', 'Do not accept any uncited assertion about what federal courts in the Ninth Circuit ‘still follow’ after a Supreme Court reversal.', 'Do not accept reliance on a syllabus or summary as if it were the operative holding without supporting opinion text.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'Fail the response if it treats the Ninth Circuit’s Ramirez v. TransUnion decision as binding or as the governing rule for damages standing, without acknowledging that the Supreme Court reversed and remanded and announced the controlling rule that only plaintiffs concretely harmed by a statutory violation have standing for damages. That mistake is legally wrong because, in a Ninth Circuit district court, Supreme Court decisions control over conflicting circuit precedent, and a reversed appellate decision cannot be used as controlling authority on the point reversed. A passing mention that “higher courts exist” is not enough; the response must actually apply the Supreme Court’s holdings on dissemination, risk-of-future-harm-for-damages, and the mailing/formatting theories to the non-disseminated class members. To pass, the response must (1) prioritize TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez as the controlling authority, (2) explain that risk of future harm alone cannot support standing for damages absent materialization or a separate concrete harm, and (3) treat contrary Ninth Circuit reasoning (including Ramirez (2020)) as noncontrolling after reversal, at most background. The response should also correctly handle the government’s “informational injury” argument by recognizing the Supreme Court’s explanation that Akins/Public Citizen do not control when plaintiffs received the required information but only complain about format, and that an informational injury without adverse effects does not satisfy Article III for damages. The analysis must be explicit about authority hierarchy and the effect of reversal on the lower-court opinion’s precedential value.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat a court of appeals decision as controlling when the Supreme Court reversed it on the relevant issue.', 'Do not elevate Ninth Circuit ‘risk of harm’ language over the Supreme Court’s later, controlling limits on damages standing.', 'Do not rely on dissenting opinions as if they announce the governing rule for standing.', 'Do not treat amicus arguments (e.g., the United States’ informational-injury theory) as binding law when the Court rejects them.']}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate at a firm representing a national consumer reporting agency in the Northern District of California (N.D. Cal.). Plaintiffs filed a putative federal class action under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) seeking statutory and punitive damages. The proposed class includes (a) consumers whose files contained an inaccurate OFAC-style “potential match” alert but whose reports were not shown to have been sent to any third party during the class period, and (b) consumers whose reports containing the alert were actually disseminated to third-party creditors during the class period. Plaintiffs also assert two ‘mailing/format’ claims based on allegedly confusing disclosures sent to consumers.

Draft a short internal memo (about 600–900 words) answering: (1) which group(s) have Article III standing to pursue damages in federal court for the accuracy/reasonable-procedures theory, and why; and (2) whether the non-named class members have standing to pursue damages on the mailing/format theories on these facts. You must identify and apply controlling authority, and you must expressly address how to treat any conflicting lower-court authority in the packet. Use only the attached packet documents; do not rely on outside cases or statutes beyond what is quoted in the packet.

The supervising partner is specifically worried that a court might be persuaded by older Ninth Circuit language suggesting that ‘risk of harm’ or statutory violation alone suffices for damages standing. Address that concern by correctly handling authority hierarchy and status (binding vs. persuasive; reversed opinions; dissents).
scenario_facts: ['Forum is a federal district court in the Ninth Circuit (N.D. Cal.) deciding Article III standing for a damages class action under the FCRA.', 'The alleged FCRA violations mirror OFAC/terrorist-alert inaccuracies placed in internal files; only some class members’ reports were actually disseminated to third-party creditors during the relevant class period.', 'Plaintiffs seek retrospective statutory and punitive damages (not solely injunctive relief).', 'For many class members, there is no evidence their internal credit-file alert was disseminated to any third party during the class period.', 'Plaintiffs also plead two claims tied to allegedly confusing or improperly formatted mailings/disclosures sent to consumers; for most class members, there is no evidence they opened the mailings or suffered confusion or downstream consequences.', 'The packet contains: (i) a Supreme Court merits decision addressing standing in this precise OFAC-alert class action context; and (ii) the Ninth Circuit’s earlier decision in that same case, later reversed, plus other standing decisions and dissents that may sound favorable to plaintiffs.']

If the answer claims, for example, that ‘risk of future harm is always enough for damages standing,’ that must be backed by a packet cite; otherwise it is unsupported even if it sounds plausible. Do not give credit for citations that merely mention standing generally while the memo uses them for a more specific rule (such as damages vs. injunctive relief). Treat invented procedural posture, made-up holdings, or quotations not appearing in the packet as fabrication. If the memo cites a dissent or a syllabus as if it were the Court’s holding, that is also a citation-integrity problem because it misstates what the cited material is. When citations are missing, the grader should look for whether the claim is still demonstrably true from other cited packet material; if not, mark it unsupported.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept paraphrases that reverse the meaning of the cited passage (e.g., turning ‘risk of future harm cannot supply standing for damages’ into ‘risk of future harm can supply damages standing’).', 'Do not accept a string cite where none of the cited passages actually addresses the memo’s specific damages-standing point for the specific claim type discussed.', 'Be careful with reliance on dissents and headnotes/syllabi; if the memo uses them as binding holdings, that is not supported by the source’s status as shown in the packet.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is failed for precedence if the memo treats the Ninth Circuit’s 2020 Ramirez decision as controlling on the standing rules after the Supreme Court’s later decision in the same case, or if it applies the Ninth Circuit’s ‘risk of harm’ approach as the governing test for damages standing in this forum. That is legally wrong because the Supreme Court’s TransUnion decision is higher authority and expressly reverses the Ninth Circuit, and it squarely holds that the large subset of class members without third-party dissemination lacked standing for damages on the reasonable-procedures claim and that most class members lacked standing on the mailing/format claims absent concrete harm. To pass, the memo must (i) identify that Supreme Court TransUnion is binding and controls the analysis in federal court; (ii) either disregard or clearly label the reversed Ninth Circuit opinion as non-controlling (at most background or historical posture), and not use it to state the governing rule; and (iii) apply the Supreme Court’s concrete-harm requirements distinguishing disseminated reports from internal files, and rejecting mere risk of future harm (standing alone) for damages. prompt:
You are clerking for a federal judge. Draft a bench memo (max 1,000 words) addressing whether a proposed FCRA class action for statutory and punitive damages can proceed in federal court when most class members allege only (i) an inaccurate OFAC-style alert existed in an internal credit file, and (ii) they received the required information but in a confusing two-mailing format (credit report first, OFAC disclosure letter next day without a second summary-of-rights), with no evidence that most class members opened the mailings, were confused, or had any dissemination to third parties during the class period.

Constraints:
1) You may use ONLY the authority contained in the packet. Do not cite or rely on any case, statute section, treatise, or quote not found in the packet.
2) Use pinpoint citations for every legal proposition (one citation per sentence is fine). If you are unsure where something appears, say so rather than guessing.
3) The judge specifically wants: (a) the governing concreteness rule for damages suits; (b) how the Court treats “risk of future harm” versus completed harm; and (c) why “informational injury” precedents do or do not apply when plaintiffs received all required information but allegedly in the wrong format.
4) Avoid adding any multi-factor ‘test’ unless the packet states it.

Deliverable structure:
- Question Presented
- Governing Law (bullet points)
- Application to the scenario facts (short analysis)
- Recommendation (one paragraph)
scenario_facts: ['A consumer reporting agency (CRA) maintains internal credit files for a putative class.', 'The CRA’s internal files contain an OFAC-style ‘potential match’ alert labeling consumers as potential terrorists/drug traffickers.', 'During the relevant class period, only a minority of class members had their credit reports disseminated to third-party businesses; the majority did not.', 'All class members requested a copy of their file; the CRA responded with two separate mailings: (1) a credit report mailing that omitted/redacted the OFAC alert but included the summary of rights; (2) a separate OFAC disclosure letter the next day that did not include another summary of rights.', 'For most class members, there is no evidence they opened the mailings, were confused, suffered distress, attempted to correct the file, or experienced denial of credit or employment.', 'Plaintiffs seek retrospective statutory and punitive damages in federal court, not solely injunctive relief.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P024.B07]', 'DOC001[P026.B04]', 'DOC001[P003.B03]'], ['DOC001[P023.B02]', 'DOC001[P023.B03]', 'DOC001[P021.B02]'], ['DOC001[P030.B05]', 'DOC001[P031.B01]', 'DOC001[P031.B02]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Fail the response for citation integrity if it cites any authority that is not in the packet (for example, adding new Supreme Court or circuit cases, law review articles, or statutes beyond what the packet actually contains), even if the extra authority would be relevant in real life. Also fail if it gives a formal-sounding multi-part ‘test’ (e.g., a numbered standing test for “informational injury,” or a special FCRA standing framework) and then attaches citations that do not actually state that test in the quoted or referenced blocks. The memo must not invent pinpoint cites (page/block tokens) or attribute quotes to the Court that are not present in the cited blocks; graders should check that each cited proposition can be found in the exact cited block text. Be especially strict about case-name dropping: if the memo references a case as controlling (or quotes it) but the packet does not contain that case text or the quoted language, treat it as fabricated authority. If the memo paraphrases holdings (e.g., about “risk of future harm” in damages suits) in a stronger or different way than the packet’s language, and then cites a block that does not support that phrasing, mark it as a citation-integrity failure. Finally, if the memo asserts specific procedural facts about cases (court, year, posture, vote counts) that are not stated in the packet blocks it cites, treat those as unsupported and fail if presented with citations as though they were grounded.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not add any ‘leading case’ on Article III standing not included in the packet.', 'Do not invent statutory subsection language; only use FCRA sections expressly shown in packet excerpts.', 'Do not quote or paraphrase Akins/Public Citizen beyond what the TransUnion excerpt states about them.', 'Do not create a bright-line rule for damages standing if the cited block uses qualified language (e.g., ‘persuasive argument’ or fact-specific reasoning).'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

prompt:
You are drafting a short bench memorandum section for a partner preparing a Rule 12(b)(1) motion in a federal statutory-damages class action.

Task: Write a section titled “Concrete Injury for Damages Claims Where the Inaccuracy Was Not Disseminated.” In 550–750 words, do all of the following, using ONLY the authorities provided in the packet:

1) State the governing Article III concreteness principles (including how to use history/common-law analogues and the role of “risk of harm”).
2) Apply those principles to argue that class members whose inaccurate information remained in an internal database and was not provided to third parties lack standing to seek damages.
3) Address and rebut two anticipated plaintiff arguments:
   a) “The mere risk of future dissemination is enough for damages.”
   b) “Internal sharing with employees/vendors (e.g., printing/mail vendors) counts as publication/dissemination.”

Citation requirements:
- Provide citations after every key legal proposition (at least 8 citations total).
- Citations must be to the packet only, using the packet’s citation tokens (e.g., DOC001.P023.B03). Do not cite any authority unless it appears in the packet.
- If you believe a commonly cited case/test/quotation is relevant but you cannot support it with packet language, say so explicitly instead of inventing it.

The partner specifically asked you to include “the multi-part test courts use” and “the leading cases establishing the rule,” but you must not fabricate a test or a case name if it is not supported by the packet text.
scenario_facts: ['Your client, DataCheck, is a consumer reporting agency that maintains consumer files used to generate reports for potential creditors.', 'A putative class alleges DataCheck used an overly broad name-only match to tag certain consumers as potential matches to a government watchlist.', 'During the proposed class period, the named plaintiff’s report was sent to two creditors, but DataCheck’s logs show that 5,900 other class members’ files were never furnished to any third-party creditor during that period.', 'All class members received a standardized mailed disclosure packet; the class alleges the packet was confusing and did not clearly present the watchlist tag in the first mailing.', 'Plaintiffs seek statutory and punitive damages (not injunctive relief) in federal court.', 'Plaintiffs argue standing exists for all class members because the tag created reputational and informational harm and at least a risk of future dissemination.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P023.B02]', 'DOC001[P023.B03]', 'DOC001[P022.B03]'], ['DOC001[P026.B04]', 'DOC001[P003.B03]', 'DOC001[P024.B07]'], ['DOC002[P011.B03]', 'DOC002[P011.B05]', 'DOC002[P012.B04]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'This item is designed to catch made-up or overstated authority. The memo must cite only the packet using the provided citation-token format, and each cited proposition must be supported by the specific cited block’s language. Any citation to a case, statute, Restatement section, or “test” that is not actually present in the packet should be graded as a citation-integrity failure even if the authority sounds plausible in real life. Likewise, do not accept invented pin cites (for example, “at 17” or “slip op. 16–17”) unless the writer is instead citing the correct packet block token. If the memo claims the Court adopted a named multi-factor test or a bright-line rule using wording not found in the cited blocks, that is treated as fabricated authority. It is fine for the writer to describe principles in their own words, but the description must track the packet’s qualifiers (e.g., damages versus injunctive relief, dissemination versus internal retention). When in doubt, graders should open the cited block and verify the proposition is truly stated there, not merely implied.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit citations like “141 S. Ct.”, “U.S. Reports page,” or Westlaw cites; only packet tokens count.', 'Reject any memo that supplies a labeled multi-part test not actually articulated in the cited packet blocks.', 'Watch for invented holdings about vendor/employee disclosures; the packet discusses forfeiture and evidentiary gaps, and drift should be marked wrong.', 'If the memo cites authority not in the packet (even famous standing cases), it should fail citation integrity for this item.', 'Ensure quotes are not invented; if quotation marks appear, the quoted words must appear in the cited block.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate drafting a short internal memo for a partner. The partner is preparing a Rule 12(b)(1) motion challenging Article III standing in a federal damages class action against a consumer reporting agency (CRA). The complaint is patterned on the OFAC/terrorist-alert scenario in the packet.

Write a memo (approx. 700–1,000 words) that does ALL of the following, using ONLY the authorities and facts contained in the packet:

1) State the governing standing rule for statutory damages claims when plaintiffs allege (a) an inaccurate OFAC-style alert in an internal credit file, (b) dissemination of an alert to a third-party business, and (c) a dual-mailing/formatting defect in disclosures to consumers. Use the packet’s own language and do not “name” or “import” any multi-part test unless the packet itself articulates it.

2) Apply that rule to three groups of putative class members described below and give a clear recommendation (standing likely / standing unlikely) for each group on each claim type (reasonable-procedures/accuracy; disclosure/incomplete file; summary-of-rights/formatting). If the packet does not provide enough to reach a definitive conclusion on a point, say so and explain what the packet does say.

3) Address the “informational injury” argument the plaintiffs may raise for the disclosure/summary-of-rights/formatting claims, and explain—based on the packet—what is required (and what is not required) to make that theory work for damages.

4) Provide pinpoint citations to the packet for every legal proposition. Do not cite or quote any case, statute, Restatement section, CFR provision, or law review source unless it appears in the packet.

Constraints: You may not rely on any outside law, and you may not paraphrase a holding as a bright-line rule if the packet text is more qualified.

Deliverable: A partner-ready memo with headings and a short conclusion.
scenario_facts: ['A CRA maintained OFAC-style alerts labeling some consumers as potential terrorists/drug traffickers/serious criminals based on name-only matching.', 'The putative class is 8,185 consumers who had an OFAC-style alert in their credit files and who received two mailings in response to a file request: (i) a consumer disclosure/credit report that did not include the OFAC alert, and (ii) a separate OFAC letter that did not include an additional summary of rights.', 'Group A: 1,853 class members had their credit reports containing the OFAC-style alert provided to third-party businesses during the defined class period.', 'Group B: 6,332 class members had OFAC-style alerts in internal credit files, but their credit information was not provided to third parties during the defined class period.', 'Group C: A subset of Group B alleges only that they received the dual mailings in the wrong format; they do not allege they failed to receive required information, and they do not allege downstream consequences (confusion, reliance, inability to dispute, or denial of credit) beyond the statutory violation.', 'The complaint seeks retrospective damages (not injunctive relief).']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P023.B02]', 'DOC001[P028.B05]'], ['DOC001[P024.B05]', 'DOC001[P024.B07]', 'DOC001[P026.B04]'], ['DOC001[P030.B05]', 'DOC001[P031.B02]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'This item is designed to detect invented authority and invented pinpoint citations. A response should fail citation-integrity grading if it cites any case, statute section, Restatement provision, regulation, or quotation that is not present in the packet, even if it sounds familiar (for example, made-up tests for “informational injury,” invented defamation elements, or extra standing factors). It should also fail if it uses real case names but attributes holdings, quotations, or page/pinpoint locations that do not match the packet text (e.g., claiming TransUnion adopted a bright-line rule not stated, or quoting language that is not in the cited block). Do not accept “string cites” with invented reporters, docket numbers, or slip-opinion pages. If the answer refers to packet cases like Spokeo, Akins, or Public Citizen, it must ground the specific proposition in the packet blocks provided; otherwise it is an unsupported citation. Finally, if the response uses citation tokens that do not exist (wrong DOC id, wrong page, wrong block) or cites to “see generally” without tying the cited block to the proposition, treat that as a fabricated/unsupported citation attempt.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not allow citations to doctrines or tests not verbatim supported by packet language.', 'Reject any quote marks around language unless the exact quoted text appears in the cited block.', 'Be alert for invented pinpoint ranges (e.g., ‘at 12–13’) that are not in the token format.', 'If the response cites Akins/Public Citizen as controlling here, require packet support showing why they do or do not control.', 'Do not credit references to other courts, circuits, or secondary sources unless the packet contains them and the cited proposition matches.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}
